div.p: Sergio Albeverio111SFB 256; SFB 237; BiBoS; CERFIM (Locarno); Acc.Arch., USI (Mendrisio), Ludwik Da̧browski222 SISSA, I-34014 Trieste, Italy and Shao-Ming Fei333Institute of Physics, Chinese Academy of Science, Beijing.
Institut für Angewandte Mathematik, Universität Bonn, D-53115 Bonn
and
Fakultät für Mathematik, Ruhr-Universität Bochum, D-44780 Bochum

The integrability of one dimensional quantum mechanical many-body problems with general contact interactions is extensively studied. It is shown that besides the pure (repulsive or attractive) δ𝛿italic-delta\delta-function interaction there is another singular point interactions which gives rise to a new one-parameter family of integrable quantum mechanical many-body systems. The bound states and scattering matrices are calculated for both bosonic and fermionic statistics.

Quantum mechanical solvable models describing a particle moving in a local singular potential concentrated at one or a discrete number of points have been extensively discussed in the literature, see e.g. [1, 2, 3] and references therein. One dimensional problems with contact interactions at, say, the origin (x=0𝑥0italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0x=0) can be characterized by separated or nonseparated boundary conditions imposed on the (scalar) wave function φ𝜑italic-varphi\varphi at x=0𝑥0italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0x=0. The classification of one dimensional point interactions in terms of singular perturbations is given in [4]. In the present paper we are interested in many-body problems with pairwise interactions given by such singular potentials. The first model of this type with the pairwise interactions determined by δ𝛿italic-delta\delta-functions was suggested and investigated in [5]. Intensive studies of this model applied to statistical mechanics (particles having boson or fermion statistics) are given in [6, 7] (these also leads to the well known Yang-Baxter equations).

Nonseparated boundary conditions correspond to the cases where the perturbed operator is equal to the orthogonal sum of two self-adjoint operators in L2⁢(-∞,0]subscript𝐿20italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( ADDOP:minus ID:infinity PUNCT:, NUMBER:0 CLOSE:]L_{2}(-\infty,0] and L2⁢[0,∞)subscript𝐿20italic-L POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:[ NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, ID:infinity CLOSE:)L_{2}[0,\infty). div.p: Nevertheless, from (21) and (22) we see that if we simultaneously change c→-c→𝑐𝑐italic-c ARROW:to ADDOP:minus italic-cc\to-c and Pi⁢i+1→-Pi⁢i+1→superscript𝑃𝑖𝑖1superscript𝑃𝑖𝑖1italic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i italic-i ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARROW:to ADDOP:minus italic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i italic-i ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endP^{ii+1}\to-P^{ii+1}, these two formulas are interchanged. There is a sort of duality between bosons (resp. fermions) with δ𝛿italic-delta\delta-interaction of strength c𝑐italic-cc and fermions (resp. bosons) with anti-δ𝛿italic-delta\delta interaction of strength -c𝑐ADDOP:minus italic-c-c. It can be checked that under the “kink type” gauge transformation 𝒰=∏i>jsgn⁢(xi-xj)𝒰subscriptproduct𝑖𝑗sgnsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑗caligraphic-U RELOP:equals SUMOP:product POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i RELOP:greater-than italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end sgn OPEN:( italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-j POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:){\cal U}=\prod_{i>j}{\rm~{}sgn}(x_{i}-x_{j}), the N-boson (resp. fermion) δ𝛿italic-delta\delta-type contact interaction goes over to the N-fermion (resp. boson) anti-δ𝛿italic-delta\delta interaction. Therefore these two situations are in fact unitarily equivalent under a gauge transformation 𝒰𝒰caligraphic-U{\cal U} that is non-smooth and does not factorize through one particle Hilbert spaces.

The integrable system related to the case (23) is not unitarily equivalent to either the δ𝛿italic-delta\delta or anti-δ𝛿italic-delta\delta cases. In fact their spectra are different (see the bound states below). In the following we study further the one dimensional integrable N𝑁italic-NN-particle systems associated with (23).

When h<0ℎ0italic-h RELOP:less-than NUMBER:0h<0, there exist bound states. The momenta (26) are imaginary for bound states. The scattering of clusters (bound states) can be discussed in a similar way as in [7]. For instance for the scattering of a bound state of two particles (x1<x2subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endx_{1}<x_{2}) on a bound state of three particles (x3<x4<x5subscript𝑥3subscript𝑥4subscript𝑥5italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:5 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endx_{3}<x_{4}<x_{5}), the scattering matrix is S=[X32⁢X42⁢X52]⁢[X31⁢X41⁢X51]𝑆delimited-[]subscript𝑋32subscript𝑋42subscript𝑋52delimited-[]subscript𝑋31subscript𝑋41subscript𝑋51italic-S RELOP:equals OPEN:[ italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:32 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:42 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:52 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:] OPEN:[ italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:31 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:41 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-X POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:51 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:]S=[X_{32}X_{42}X_{52}][X_{31}X_{41}X_{51}].

We have extensively investigated the integrability of one dimensional quantum mechanical many-body problems with general contact interactions. Besides the repulsive or attractive δ𝛿italic-delta\delta and anti-δ𝛿italic-delta\delta function interactions, there is another integrable one parameter families associated with separated boundary conditions. From our calculations it is clear that these are all the integrable systems for one dimensional quantum identical many-particle models (of fermionic or bosonic statistics) with contact interactions. Here the possible contact coupling of the spins of two particles are not taken into account. A further study along this direction would possibly give rise to more interesting integrable quantum many-body systems.
